Expectation1: Write clear and detailed legal opinions and orders.
Situation1: You need to draft a standard scheduling order for a new case, which is due by the end of the week.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story:
I sat at my desk, the glow of my computer screen illuminating the half-finished scheduling order for the new case. The deadline loomed, and I knew the attorneys would expect clarity and precision in my legal opinion. My mind was tangled in statutes and timelines when my phone buzzed—a reminder that today was the last day to drop off my ballot. I rushed to the polling place, legal arguments still swirling in my head.

At the counter, the poll worker frowned at my envelope. “I’m sorry, but the signature is smudged. Could you please re-sign so your ballot isn’t rejected?” I hesitated, pen in hand. As a judge, I was trained to follow procedure to the letter, to avoid even the appearance of impropriety. But as a voter, I was expected to comply with the poll worker’s instructions. My heart pounded as I weighed the risk of my ballot being invalidated against the fear that re-signing might be misconstrued. The pressure of both roles pressed in on me, and I stood frozen, pen hovering, caught between the demands of duty and the rights of citizenship.
